passages.text: Kingfisher 1H preview, French FMCG sales, ASDA 2Q sales

Morning's headlines (full stories below)- \*\*BARCLAYS RESEARCH: Kingfisher - 1H preview (due 23 Sep)\*\*- \*\*BARCLAYS RESEARCH: French Food Retail - Market share - FMCG sales slow sharply\*\*- \*\*BARCLAYS RESEARCH: Boohoo - FY25 model update; strategy becoming clearer but outlook tough\*\*- ASDA 2Q25 sales.- Waitrose trials Al smart trolley system.- ASDA trialling Al cameras to monitor availability.- Former WH Smith CFO delays Greggs role amid accounting investigation.- ASDA to resume Express store opening program.- Poundland to roll out new grocery pricing.
UK Mid & Small Cap Leisure/Consumer NEUTRAL  Unchanged  European Food Retail  NEUTRAL  Unchanged  European General Retail  NEUTRAL  Unchanged  European Internet  POSITIVE  Unchanged
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 12. Completed: 29-Aug- 25, 07:39 GMT Released: 29-Aug- 25, 07:39 GMT Restricted - External
FIGURE 1. French FMCG sales slow to +0.4% in the 4w to 10 August (from +4.2% in 4w to 13 July)
Source: Worldpanel by Numerator, Barclays Research

\\*\\*IN- PERSON\\*\\* Barclays 18th Annual Global Consumer Staples Conference (2- 4 September) The Barclays 18th Annual Global Consumer Staples Conference will be held at the InterContinental Boston. Anchored on presentations, fireside chats, and on- one meetings, the conference will feature a variety of Consumer Staples and Retail companies. The presenting speakers will include senior management from the following consumer segments: Food and Drug, Household & Personal Care, Beverages and Tobacco. European attendance: AAK, ABI, AD, BARN, BAYER, BEI, BAT, BN, CARLB, CPR, DGE, ESSITY, GIVN, GLB, HLN, HEIA, HEN3, IMB, JDEP, KYG, LINDT, NESN, NSISB, OR, PUIG, RI, RKT, RCO, SY1, TATE, ULVR.

\\*\\*IN- PERSON\\*\\* Jerónimo Martins Investor Trip in Warsaw (30 September) Please join us for a trip to Warsaw, Poland, where we will be hosting a meeting with the Biedronka CEO (1:00- 2:30pm) followed by a store tour (2:45- 4:00pm). This trip is convenient timing for those attending the Zabka Group investor event that is due to start that evening at 8:00pm in Warsaw.

\\*\\*SAVE THE DATE\\*\\* Barclays: European Retail Forum 2025 (7/14/21 November) Three days of virtual fireside chats with senior management from key European retailers including Ahold Delhaize, B&M, Carrefour, Dunelm, Greggs, H&M, JD Sports, Jerónimo Martins, M&S, NEXT, Pepco, Sainsbury, Tesco, Zabka, Zalando and 3i (Action). More companies will be added to the line- up. A detailed timetable will be released in September, but please 'save the date' in your calendar.

\\*\\*BARCLAYS RESEARCH: Kingfisher - 1H preview (due 23 Sep)\\*\\* We update our model following Kingfisher's 1Q25/26 trading statement. LFL sales were better than we expected in the UK and France, driven primarily by weather- sensitive seasonal categories, but behind our expectations in Poland, with the company citing geopolitical factors that are weighing on sentiment. We suspect the strong outcome partly reflects pulled- forward demand from 2Q25/26 - especially given seasonal products are typically 'once- a- season' purchases (e.g., barbecues). Indeed, Kingfisher reiterated its relatively wide PBT guidance range (c.£480m to £540m), which supports the notion that strong 1Q trends should not necessarily be extrapolated forward through the rest of the year. We increase our FY25/26 PBT forecast to £525m from £520m (vs Bloomberg consensus of £522m) - assuming roughly half of the 1Q25/26 sales beat was a 'genuine' beat and roughly half was pulled- forward demand from 2Q25/26. Our EPS estimates rise by \(+0.8\%\) for FY25/26 but remain unchanged for the next two years. We reiterate our Underweight stock rating, with an unchanged price target of 280p. Next event is 1H25/26 results on 23 September. On our numbers, Kingfisher trades on a FY25/26 PE of 13.3x.\\*

\\*\\*BARCLAYS RESEARCH: French Food Retail - Market share - FMCG sales slow sharply\\*\\* The overall market grew by \(+0.4\%\) in the four weeks to 10 August - this compares with \(+4.2\%\) in the four weeks to 13 July and \(+1.6\%\) YTD. Looking at the different channels: Online gained \(+0.4\) ppts of share (to \(10.0\%\) ); convenience stores collectively gained \(+0.1\) ppts of share (to \(8.3\%\) ), discounters gained \(+0.2\) ppts of share (to \(11.4\%\) ), supermarkets lost - 0.6 ppts of share (to \(30.8\%\) ) and hypermarkets lost - 0.2 ppts of share (to \(39.4\%\) ). Overall Carrefour's market share contracted by - 1 ppts YoY - this compared with an average YoY gain of \(+1.7\) ppts in the preceding 12 weeks. Within Carrefour's overall market share performance, hypermarkets (inc online) gained \(+0.1\) ppts
(vs average gain of \(+1.2\) ppts in the preceding 12 weeks), supermarkets lost - 0.2ppts (vs preceding 12- week loss of - 0.2ppts) and convenience was flat (vs preceding 12- week gains of 0.1ppts).^

\*\*BARCLAYS RESEARCH: Boohoo - FY25 model update; strategy becoming clearer but outlook tough\*\* Boohoo is in the early stages of a multi- year turnaround strategy. Performance recovery of the company now rests on three key pillars: scaling Debenhams' asset- light marketplace model across the Group, expanding margins, and 'right- sizing' the Youth Brands, which we view as the most structurally challenged. While Debenhams is showing encouraging growth, its current scale is small (- £650m GMV). We remain cautious on the feasibility of replicating the asset- light model across the Youth Brands, where operational complexity and brand positioning may limit its effectiveness. Although the mid- term strategy is becoming clearer, we believe it will take time to translate into results, and Boohoo's outlook remains challenged. A potential sale of PLT could unlock some value for the Group, though we expect any valuation to be materially below what Boohoo originally paid & no obvious buyer at this stage. We still don't forecast positive FCF (post SBC, leases) until FY27 and positive EPS until FY29. Boohoo trades on - 7x '26E EV/EBITDA - more expensive than Zalando (- 5x), which has both FCF and EPS making a valuation easier to underpin. The balance sheet is looking better post- refi but is still stretched (net debt at FY25 of - £78m). We prefer names in our coverage with positive and accelerating growth, well capitalised balance sheets, and near- term FCF/EPS support.\*\*

ASDA 2Q25 sales. ASDA (private) reported 2Q25 results yesterday, covering April to June. 2Q LFL sales (excl. fuel) declined by - 0.2%. Adjusted for Easter timing, LFL sales declined by - 1.1%, marking a 2ppt sequential improvement from the - 3.1% LFL for Jan- Apr (given as a proxy for Easter adjusted 1Q performance). Overall, 1H LFL sales declined by - 2.4%, while total revenue (ex- fuel) of £10.3bn declined - 3.1% YoY (incl. - 0.5ppt negative calendar impact from leap year). ASDA Express delivered +8.6% LFL growth (vs +6% in 1Q), outperforming the convenience market. George delivered +2.5% LFL growth (vs +3.5% in 1Q). On strategic progress: i) ASDA highlights rollback price cuts on >50% of products (- 14,000 SKUs vs >10,000 in 1Q), with an average reduction of 22%. ASDA's own inflation rate remains "significantly lower" than the +5% market rate in August; ii) Product availability increased to 96% - its highest level in eight years - which compares with 90% in January; iii) Project Future (IT system separation from Walmart) is now complete (as of last week) with all stores, food depots and head offices operating on the new IT system. Allan Leighton, Asda's Executive Chairman, said that the "collective rate of [Project Future] completion did cause some temporary disruption with product availability and in our online experience, which will impact our sales outturn in the current quarter." Leighton still expects to exit the year in LFL growth.\^

Waitrose trials Al smart trolley system. Waitrose is trialling an Al system that identifies items as shoppers place them into their trolleys at its Bracknell store, reported The Grocer yesterday. Shoppers scan the barcodes on items as they would with a self- scan handset in front of the device, then place it in the trolley. Once placed, back- facing cameras verify the product. The devices are stored in a charging bank near the entrance to the store and released once a customer has scanned their loyalty card. Customers are required to weigh loose produce at an in- aisle scale and then scan the barcode before placing the item in the trolley. The devices are supplied by Shopic, which says supermarkets can use location data from the devices to see how long shoppers spent in each aisle, their "shelf interactions", and their route around a store, as well as being a platform for retail media as the large screen on the devices can also be used to serve "contextually relevant ads and offers". The Bracknell store is also trialling shelf inventory cameras from Focal Systems to give store staff "real- time information on what products are out of stock" as well as electronic shelf labels Solum to "simplify price and compliance processes", according to a spokesperson.\^

ASDA trialling Al cameras to monitor availability. ASDA is trialling Al- powered cameras from Focal Systems that scan shelves every hour to detect in- stock and low and out- of- stock products, as well as spoiled produce and planogram non- compliance, reported The Grocer yesterday. ASDA is trialling the new technology in five stores.^

Former WH Smith CFO delays Greggs role amid accounting investigation. Robert Moorhead, former CFO and COO at WH Smith, has requested to defer his appointment to the board of Greggs until after the ongoing accounting review at WH Smith.^

ASDA to resume Express store opening program. Asda announced yesterday that it will resume its Express convenience store opening program in early October, with up to 20 new stores planned. These new locations will expand Asda's presence in high- footfall urban areas, residential locations, and transport hubs, where it has traditionally had limited presence. The program starts with the launch of a Castleford Asda Express site in early October, followed by openings in up to 20 more UK locations from late October onwards.^

Poundland to roll out new grocery pricing. Poundland is rolling out a new grocery pricing structure to all of its UK stores, with all ranges set at three price points - £1, £2, £3, - as it scraps additional price complexity, reported Retail Gazette yesterday. The new pricing has been piloted at 17 West Midlands stores over the last five months, and will now be rolled out across the whole store estate between now and September. Once complete, around 60% of grocery items will be priced at £1, 20% at £2, and 20% at £3. Poundland will also extend this simplicity structure to its general merchandise and clothing ranges over the coming months.^

The Nielsen material contained in this report represents Nielsen estimates and does not represent facts. Nielsen has neither reviewed nor approved this report and/or any of the statement made herein.
Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

On 29-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Underweight, and the adjusted price target was 0.45.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: We value Boohoo on a DCF with \(3\%\) terminal growth and an \(11.6\%\) WACC, with a \(12\%\) terminal ROCE.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks to the upside include 1) faster growth than we anticipate - particularly internationally, 2) better- than- expected contribution from recent M&A, 3) supply chain improvements, and 4) more moderate competition.

Barclays | Retail Detail (Kingfisher 1H preview, French FMCG sales, ASDA 2Q sales)
On 29-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Overweight, and the adjusted price target was 22.00.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

Valuation Methodology: We value Carrefour by taking an average of the valuations generated by a DCF and a 'sum-of-the-parts'. 'DCF. We use a common DCF methodology for all our companies (formulaic fade rates, capex fading towards depreciation, etc). The two key inputs - apart from WACC, which is necessarily somewhat subjective - are for the terminal margin and growth rates. For Carrefour we assume a terminal EBIT margin of 3.4%, slightly up compared with the level we forecast in 2027E. We think this is realistic given the structural constraints on the company's margins (formats, real estate, franchises). We assume 1.5% terminal sales growth, which is at the lower end of the 1.0-2.5% range that we use for companies in the sector - reflecting its exposure to a mix of mature European markets and developing markets. 'Sum-of-the-parts. We apply different EV/sales multiples on the various segments, reflecting their expected profit margins and growth rates. We are most generous with the French convenience business (c35%), Spain (35%) and Brazil (35%) and most cautious with French hypermarkets (22%). Both methodologies generate a value of approximately £15.75 and we use this as our price target.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The three main risks we see to our Overweight rating on Carrefour are as follows: 1) Competitive risk - the possibility that competition steps back up in France. 2) FX risk - especially in relation to the Brazilian and Argentine currencies against the euro. 3) Macro backdrop - the possibility that consumer spending remains depressed in Carrefour's key markets of France, Spain and Brazil.

Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

Valuation Methodology: As with all the companies we cover, we use a discounted cash flow (DCF) methodology to value Kingfisher. We also use a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) methodology given that Kingfisher comprises a number of businesses with quite different growth characteristics and margin structures. Our price target is the average of the DCF and SOTP. In our DCF we assume terminal sales growth of \(2.3\%\) (in line with what we expect in the final year of our explicit forecasts) and a terminal EBITDA margin of \(11.0\%\) . We use a WACC of \(9.7\%\) . In our SOTP for most of the segments we start

by applying an EV/sales multiple, but we choose that multiple with reference to the implied EV/EBIT multiple it generates for 25/26E. (We tend to prefer EV/EBIT rather than EV/EBITDA because of the different capital intensities of the various segments.) We apply higher multiples to the faster growing businesses, notably Screwfix and stores in Poland, although we also use higher multiples for the segments where we still see recovery potential (e.g. Castorama France).

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The main risks to the upside include the following: Lower interest rates could stimulate the housing market and create demand for home improvement products. If we get evidence of the Screwfix model working well in France then this could create hopes of a long- term profitable rollout opportunity. French and Polish margins have reduced sharply in the last few years - if we see signs of recovery then this may create hope of sustained improvement. The main risks to the downside include the following: Screwfix is starting to open stores in France; if this move does not go well then the market might reconsider the banner's long- term growth potential. Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a

company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated.
